Right now I don't have a great place to ask math questions just as they pop into my head - questions that may seem trivial or even stupid moments later. (Maybe I shouldn't post such questions? But sometimes that helps me figure out that answer, and sometimes they turn out to be interesting.)

For category theory I don't mind asking such questions here. But these two are actually analysis. The first one is more standard, but the second is the one I really care about.

Question 1. Suppose we have a series

f(x)=∑i=0∞aixi f(x) = \sum_{i = 0}^\infty a_i x^i f(x)=∑i=0∞​ai​xi

with each ai≥0a_i \ge 0ai​≥0. Is the following true?

Either the series diverges for all x>0x > 0x>0, or there exists some RRR such that the series converges for 0≤x<R0 \le x < R0≤x<R and diverges for x≥Rx \ge Rx≥R.

My guess is yes. This would be a sense in which "convergence is an open condition". I'm mainly trying to rule out the possibility that it converges for 0≤x≤R0 \le x \le R0≤x≤R but diverges for x>Rx > Rx>R. There are also, a priori, other possibilities, but I think these are easier to rule out.

I also guess that f(x)→+∞f(x) \to +\inftyf(x)→+∞ as xxx approaches RRR from below, and I'd like to know this too if true.

Question 2. Suppose we have a series

f(x)=∑i=0∞exp⁡(−aix) f(x) = \sum_{i = 0}^\infty \exp(-a_i x) f(x)=∑i=0∞​exp(−ai​x)

where ai∈Ra_i \in \mathbb{R}ai​∈R. Is the following true?

Either the series diverges for all x≥0x \ge 0x≥0, or there exists some R>0R > 0R>0 such that the series converges for x>Rx > Rx>R and diverges for 0≤x≤R.0 \le x \le R.0≤x≤R.

Note that in this second one, if we assume the series converges for some x≥0x \ge 0x≥0, it must be true that the aia_iai​ are bounded below, and there must be only finitely many ≤A\le A≤A for any A∈RA \in \mathbb{R}A∈R. Thus we can assume without loss of generality that a1≤a2≤a3≤⋯a_1 \le a_2 \le a_3 \le \cdots a1​≤a2​≤a3​≤⋯, since we're free to rearrange terms in a sequence whose terms are all positive.
For question 1, what about x+x2/4+x3/9+…x + x^2/4 + x^3/9 + \ldotsx+x2/4+x3/9+… which converges at x=1x = 1x=1 but not for x>1x > 1x>1?

Oh, duh, thanks. I knew about that - I just wasn't engaging my history of teaching calculus. :grimacing: That's exactly what I meant by firing off a question just as it came into my head.

So now maybe I can come up with a counterexample to the one I'm really interested in, question 2.

For a counterexample I want to find a series

∑i=0∞exp⁡(−aix) \sum_{i = 0}^\infty \exp(-a_i x)∑i=0∞​exp(−ai​x)

and an x>0x > 0x>0 that makes it converge, but for which no smaller xxx makes it converge.

In case anyone is curious about why I care: it's because I'm writing about the Hagedorn temperature in my little book Tweets on Entropy. This is a temperature above which the partition function of some system diverges so the statistical mechanics of that system makes no sense. Basically it gets so hot that all hell breaks loose. :fire: :fire: :fire:

My intuition is that when a Hagedorn temperature exists, the partition function must diverge at the Hagedorn temperature. If the answer to question 2 is "yes, your claim is true", then my intuition is right. Todd has just shaken that intuition. But it's possible question 2 works differently from question 1.

(By the way: for anyone who cares, Wikipedia defines Hagedorn temperature in a way that assumes my intuition is right! They don't consider the possibility that the partition function is well-defined that Hagedorn temperature but diverges at all higher temperatures. They only consider the possibility where the partition function approaches infinity as you approach the Hagedorn temperature and is thus (one can show) divergent at that temperature.)
Anyway, my questions deliberately stripped off all this physics, because you don't need to know physics to answer question 2!

The quantity exp(−aix)\mathrm{exp}(-a_ix)exp(−ai​x) is the same as exp(−ai)x\mathrm{exp}(-a_i)^xexp(−ai​)x. Pick aia_iai​ so that exp(−ai)=1ilog(i)2\mathrm{exp}(-a_i) = \frac{1}{i\mathrm{log}(i)^2}exp(−ai​)=ilog(i)21​. Then when x=1x = 1x=1 the sum of 1ilog(i)2\frac{1}{i\mathrm{log}(i)^2}ilog(i)21​ converges, but when x<1x < 1x<1 the sum of 1ixlog(i)2x\frac{1}{i^x\mathrm{log}(i)^{2x}}ixlog(i)2x1​ diverges.

Nice! Thanks so much, @Oscar Cunningham. I was trying something less clever, like exp⁡(−ai)=1/i2\exp(-a_i) = 1/i^2exp(−ai​)=1/i2. Somehow I failed to use all my wonderful knowledge, like that the sum of 1/nlog⁡n1/n \log n1/nlogn diverges but 1/n(log⁡n)21/n (\log n)^21/n(logn)2 converges, and so on.
Okay, so the answer to question 2 is "false": the borderline case can go either way.
Didn't you say ai∈Ra_i \in \Rai​∈R? Does Oscar's answer still apply?

Yes, I foolishly used iii to mean 1,2,3,…1, 2, 3, \dots1,2,3,… and Oscar kindly went along with me. So all the numbers here are real, even though they look iii-maginary.
